Graphical abstract Highlights ► Preparation and characterization of rice husk supported FeCl3 nanoparticles (FeCl3-RiH). ► Application of FeCl3-RiH in the promotion of the acylation of aldehydes. ► Deprotection of 1,1-diacetates catalyzed by FeCl3-RiH. ► Catalysis under solvent-free conditions. ► Heterogeneous catalysis and recyclability of the catalyst. 1,1-Diacetates were produced from a variety of aromatic aldehydes using rice husk supported FeCl3 nanoparticles as a catalyst. The procedure generally resulted in good yields (98%) of aromatic aldehydes including those carrying electron donating- or withdrawing-substituents. Deprotection of the resulting 1,1-diacetates was also achieved using the same catalyst in ethanol. This new method consistently has the advantages of excellent yields and relatively short reaction times. Further, the catalyst can be reused and recovered for several times. Keywords Rice husk supported FeCl3 nanoparticles (FeCl3-RiH) 1,1-Diacetates Aldehydes Heterogeneous catalyst Deprotection 1 Introduction Protection of aldehydes is a frequently desired exercise in organic synthesis as it is often necessary to carry out a reaction on a multifunctional substrate without affecting α-carbonyl group [1]. Aldehydes are often protected by acetalization through reaction between aldehydes and alcohols [2] or trimethyl orthoformate [3] and by the reaction of aldehydic compound with acetic anhydride in the presence of a Brönsted acid or Lewis acid, which act as a catalyst. Among these methods, protection of aldehydes as their corresponding 1,1-diacetates has attracted the attention of many organic chemists. This attention can be attributed to their remarkable stability to neutral and basic conditions [4], and their applicability as building blocks for asymmetric allylic alkylation and Diel's Alder reaction [5,6]. Some of the reagents and catalysts that have recently been employed for the promotion of this type of reactions are: LiOTf [7], ceric ammonium nitrate [8], InCl3 [9], H2NSO3H [10], LiBF4 [11], H2SO4 [12], PCl3 [13], NBS [14], I2 [15], TMSCl-NaI [16], FeCl3 [17], and Bi(NO3)3·5H2O [18]. Some metal triflates, such as Cu(OTf)2 [19], and Sc(OTf)3 [20], in environmentally harmful organic solvents (e.g., CH2Cl2 [21–24], CH3CN [24], CH3NO2 [25]), have also been utilized as catalysts for the preparation of 1,1-diacetate derivatives from the corresponding aldehydes. Many of these methods have certain drawbacks, such as long reaction time, involvement of expensive reagents, use of additional reagents, requirement of special effort for catalyst preparation, need to use special apparatus, moderate yields, and side reactions. The most serious drawback is that these methods have no global utility and most of the products are liquid, which may contain impurities and are difficult to be purified compared to the powder and crystal. Furthermore, many of these methods involve cumbersome product isolation procedure and there are only a few reagents, such as: CAN [8], ZrCl4 [26], InBr3 [27], and poly(4-vinylpyridinium) hydrogen sulfate [28], which are applicable to both, the synthesis of acylals as well as for their conversion to parent carbonyls. Therefore, there is a scope to find out an alternative method, which might be mild and catalytically efficient. The above mentioned subjects encouraged us to prepare the rice husk supported FeCl3 nanoparticles as a new, efficient and heterogeneous reagent. Our investigations clarified that this reagent is efficiently able to catalyze the chemoselective protection of aldehydes as their corresponding 1,1-diacetates and deprotection of the obtained acylals. All reactions are performed under mild reaction conditions in short reaction times in good to high yields. 2 Experimental 2.1 General Chemicals were purchased from Fluka, Merck, Aldrich and Southern Clay Products Chemical Companies. Yields refer to isolated products. Products were characterized by their physical constants, comparison with authentic samples and IR and NMR spectroscopy. The purity determination of the substrate and reaction monitoring were accomplished by TLC on silica-gel polygram SILG/UV 254 plates. 2.2 Instrumentation The IR spectra were run on a Perkin-Elmer bio-spectrometer and Bruker Vector 22. The 1H NMR (400MHz) and 13C NMR (100MHz) were run on a Bruker AVANCEIII-400 spectrometer in CDCl3 using TMS as an internal reference (δ in ppm). Microanalyses were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240-B microanalyzer. Melting points were recorded on a Büchi B-545 apparatus in open capillary tubes. The characterization of rice husk was obtained using scanning electron microscopy (SEM-Philips XL30) with field emission gun and energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS). Prior to placing into the microscope, the rice husk particles were coated with gold under vacuum (SCD 005 sputter coater, Bal-Tec, Swiss) and examined at an acceleration voltage of 17kV. X-ray diffractometry (XRD) diagrams of the samples were obtained with a diffractometer Model XRD 6000, PHILIPS Xpert pro. The chemical composition of RHA was analyzed using X-ray fluorescence (XRF) spectrometer (Model Magix Pro, Philips). 2.3 Preparation of rice husk Rice sample (named as Hassani) was obtained from Rasht (Guilan Provience) in the north of Iran. Rice husk was obtained from a local mill, washed several times with distilled water to remove any adhering materials and dried at room temperature for 48h. The dried RiH smashed and sieved (80–170 mesh size), washed with distilled water and dried at 110°C for 4h. The main components of the rice husk sample were determined as follow, using the reported methods in the literature [29,30]: silica (14.2%), cellulose (27.4%), hemicelluloses (18.3%), lignin (25.8%), inorganic residue (9.3%), and moisture (5%). 2.4 Preparation of the catalyst (FeCl3-RiH) The catalyst was prepared by impregnation of rice husk (RiH) (50g) with a solution of anhydrous FeCl3 (0.053mol, 8.62g) in acetone. The solvent was evaporated under reduced pressure and the catalyst was heated at 120°C for 8h to give FeCl3-rice husk (58g). 2.5 Catalyst characterization 2.5.1 IR analysis Fig. 1 shows the FTIR spectra of the RiH and FeCl3-RiH. The spectra are virtually identical. This implied that FTIR is not sensitive to change in the system. In the stretching region, two peaks at 3400–3480cm−1 and 2950–2970cm−1 are observed in both of spectra. The broad band in the range 3430–3480cm−1 is due to the stretching vibration of OH bond. This band is due to the silanol OH groups and the adsorbed water bound to the silica surface, and the peak at about 2900cm−1 is due to the CH stretching from aliphatic saturated compounds [31]. 1600–1750cm−1 and 1400–1600cm−1, assigned to CO stretching of hemicelluloses and lignin and CC stretching of aromatic carbon respectively [32]. The strong peaks between 1025 and 1100cm−1 are due to the structural siloxane bond, SiOSi. These peaks are observed in both RiH and metal incorporated RiH. The band at 800–805 and 460–475cm−1 in all spectra are due to the deformation of SiO bond. In the FeCl3-RiH spectra the shoulder at 910cm−1 is due to the FeOSi vibration [33]. 2.5.2 SEM analysis Fiber sizes and shapes are one of the most important factors for composite materials. The effective surface area which may have influence on chemical properties depends on particle size and shape. Figs. 2 and 3 show the SEM micrographs of the rice husk and rice husk supported FeCl3 nano-particles, respectively. Fig. 2a shows layering sequences of phyllosilicate [34] and Fig. 2b shows particle size and shape of the rice husk. There are different types of fiber shape observed. Most of the particles are round and angular. Particle size (length) distribution is not same. All these samples show a structure mainly formed by elongated pores (tubular). The sizes of the pores are about 3–10μm. The micrographs reveal clearly the presence of cylindrical structures, with different diameters, after metal ion sorption (Fig. 3a–d); these structures were absent on the rice bran before the sorption process. Covered on the substrate, the FeCl3 of RiH are nanoparticles with diameters of 100–900nm (Fig. 3c). The SEM observations prove that the rice husk supported FeCl3 nano-particles catalyst have been successfully prepared. The presence of pellets on the rice bran particles and inside the cylindrical structures can also be observed after metal ion sorption. The results are in accordance with the earlier report [35]. 2.6 XRD analysis The XRD patterns of the samples are shown in Fig. 4 . As indicated by the featureless diffractometers and the appearance of a diffuse maximum at 2θ =25.5, which is typical for amorphous silica [36], it can be concluded that the rice husk and FeCl3-rice husk (Fig. 4) are completely amorphous and did not show crystalline structure. The XRD patterns of FeCl3-RiH also show a decrease in the line intensities after the addition of FeCl3 to the rice husk sample. 2.7 XRF analysis X-ray fluorescence (XRF) is the emission of characteristic “secondary” (or fluorescent) X-rays from a material that has been excited by bombarding with high energy X-rays or gamma rays. XRF technology provides one of the simplest, most accurate and most economic analytical methods for the determination of the chemical composition of many types of materials. The loss on ignition (L.O.I.) of RiH and FeCl3-RiH is determined by heating 3g of each sample at 1000°C for 1h in air to remove the moisture and the coexisting unburned carbon. Table 1 shows the percentage of the elements of RiH with silica as the major element (∼16.54%). Other metallic elements are also present in RiH as minor elements. The composition of rice husk supported with FeCl3 nanoparticles determined by XRF are listed in Table 1. The results clearly show that the Fe content is increased in FeCl3-RiH. 2.8 General procedure for the acetylation of aldehydes Aldehyde (1mmol), acetic anhydride (2.5mmol), and FeCl3-rice husk (0.02g) were mixed at room temperature. The reaction was monitored by TLC. After completion of the reaction ethylacetate (15mL) was added to the reaction mixture and the catalyst was recovered by filtration, and washed with ethylacetate (5mL). The organic layer was washed with a saturated solution of NaHCO3 (3×15mL) and water (2×10mL). The organic phase was dried over anhydrous MgSO4, filtered and the solvent was evaporated to give the pure desired compounds. The solid crude product that obtained was purified by recrystallization from cyclohexane, or by column chromatography on a silica gel column. The spectral (IR, 1H and 13C NMR) data of new compounds are presented below: A: Table 3 , entry 9: white solid, m.p. 164–166°C; IR (KBr): 3020, 2910, 1758, 1430, 1378, 1338, 1200, 1118, 1060, 1008, 960, 940, 910, 852, 818, 604, 580, and 540cm−1. 1H NMR (300MHz, CDCl3): 2.37 (s, 6H, 2× COCH3), 7.29 (d, 1H, J =5.7Hz, ArH), 7.41 (d, 1H, J =5.1Hz, ArH), 8.26 (s, 1H, CH(OAc)2) ppm; 13C NMR (75MHz, DMSO): 167.00, 141.19, 129.82, 104.33, and 21.55ppm. B: Table 3, entry 10: white solid, m.p. 65–67°C; IR (KBr): 3650, 3500, 3010, 2910, 1760, 1610, 1590, 1490, 1430, 1370, 1245, 1200, 1160, 1060, 1010, 970, 940, 917, 790, 760, 700, 670, and 600cm−1. 1H NMR (300MHz, DMSO-d6): ı 2.13 (s, 6H, 2× COCH3), 3.38 (s, 3H, CH3), 7.02 (d, 1H, J =7.9Hz, ArH), 7.50 (d, 1H, J =7.9Hz, ArH), 7.60–7.66 (m, 2H, J =8.3, J =7.7Hz, ArH), 8.04 (s, 1H, CH(OAc)2) ppm; 13C NMR (75MHz, DMSO-d6): ı 167.55, 147.74, 135.42, 133.82, 127.94, 125.12, 123.53, 87.83, 21.93, and 21.00ppm. C: Table 3, entry 15: white solid, m.p. 96–98°C; IR (KBr): 3002, 2920, 1752, 1430, 1362, 1340, 1240, 1200, 1158, 1106, 1060, 1000, 942, 910, 808, 710, 680, 650, 600, 530, and 510cm−1. 1H NMR (300MHz, DMSO-d6): 2.10 (s, 12H, 4× COCH3), 7.52 (d, 1H, J =7.8Hz, ArH), 8.00 (d, 1H, J =7.9Hz, ArH), 8.17 (s, 1H, CH(OAc)2), 8.43 (dd, 2H, J =7.6, J =8.2Hz, ArH) ppm; 13C NMR (75MHz, DMSO-d6): 167.00, 141.19, 129.62, 128.82, 126.32, 102.33, and 22.55ppm. 2.9 General procedure for deprotection of 1,1-diacetates A solution of the substrate (1mmol) in EtOH (3mL) was stirred as FeCl3-rice husk (0.08g) was added. The mixture was stirred and heated at 70°C. The progress of the reaction was monitored by TLC. After completion of the reaction, the mixture was filtered to separate the solid catalyst. The combined filtrates were concentrated on a rotary evaporator to remove EtOH. Water (5mL) was added and the product was extracted with Et2O (3–5mL). The organic layer was washed with a saturated solution of NaHCO3 and dried over MgSO4. The solvent was evaporated under reduced pressure. The resultant product was passed through a short column of silica gel (n-hexan–EtOAc, 9:1) to afford pure aldehyde. 3 Results and discussion In recent years, investigation on the application of silica-based reagents in organic reactions became an important part of our ongoing research program [37–41]. In continuation of these studies, we were interested to investigate the applicability of rice husk (RiH), as a source of amorphous silica [42], in these type of reactions. Herein, and for the first time we report the preparation of rice husk supported FeCl3 nano-particles (FeCl3-RiH) and its application in the efficient and chemoselective conversion of aldehydes to their corresponding 1,1-diacetates with acetic anhydride and deprotection of the obtained 1,1-diacetates. All reactions are performed under mild reaction conditions in good to high yields. First of all and for obtaining the optimum reaction conditions, we studied the influence of the following factors on the protection of benzaldeyde with acetic anhydride: (i) the amounts of FeCl3 and the size of RiH sample used for the preparation of the catalyst; (ii) solvent, and (iii) temperature. The results showed that the best results can be obtained under conditions showed in Scheme 1 using 0.02g of the catalyst prepared from the addition of 8.62g FeCl3 on RiH (50g, mesh 80–170) (Table 2 , entry 4). To illustrate the efficiency of the catalyst in these reactions, acylation of benzaldehyde was also carried out in the absence of the catalyst (Table 4 , entries 11). The reaction was not completed after a long reaction time. This result indicates that the catalyst is necessary to produce the acylal product. Following the above reaction condition, a variety of aromatic aldehydes are converted to the corresponding 1,1-diacetates under solvent free conditions using acetic anhydride in the presence of FeCl3-RiH at room temperature in excellent yields and short reaction times. As shown in Table 3, benzylic aldehydes, including different substituents such as F, Cl, Br, CN, NO2, CH3 and OCH3 are converted to their corresponding acylals in good to high yields (Table 3, entries 1–18). This method is also very useful for the protection of aliphatic aldehydes (Table 3, entries 19 and 20). Furthermore, α,β-unsaturated aldehydes, such as cinnamaldehyde (Table 3, entry 21) and acid sensitive aldehydes, such as furfural (Table 3, entry 22) reacted well without any decomposition or polymerization under the selected reaction conditions. Under the same reaction conditions acylation of ketones was not successful and the starting material was recovered unchanged after 2h (Table 3, entry 23). Therefore, the method can be useful for the chemoselective acylation of aldehydes in the presence of ketones. After completion of the reaction, the catalyst was washed well with ethylacetate, and then dried at 100°C prior to used and tested for its activity in subsequent run and fresh catalyst was not added. It was seen that the catalyst displayed very good reusability (Fig. 5 ). The possible mechanism for the acylation of various aldehydes in the presence of FeCl3-RiH as a promoter is shown in Scheme 2 . On the basis of this mechanism, FeCl3-RiH catalyzes the reaction by the electrophilic activation of the aldehyde to form a zwitterionic species, making the carbonyl group susceptible to nucleophilic attack by AC2O. Successive intermolecular or intramolecular transfer to the second acetate group results in the formation of 1,1-diacetate derivatives and regenerates the catalyst in the reaction. The advantages of FeCl3-RiH over reported catalysts for the acylation of p-methylbenzaldehyde are shown in Table 4. It is noteworthy that some of the previously reported methods require longer reaction times. Having established the preferred reaction conditions, the deprotection of several representative acylals was also performed to demonstrate the versatility and uniqueness of the present reaction conditions (Table 3). Aromatic acylals were converted to the parent aldehydes in impressive yield (Scheme 1, Table 3, entries 1–18). Aliphatic 1,1-diacetates also converted to their aldehydes in short time and high yields (Table 1, entries 19, 20). α,β-Unsaturated acylals (Table 1, entry 21) were also proved amicable to this methodology. 2-Furanylmethanediol diacetate (Table 1, entry 22) also was converted to its corresponding aldehyde without polymerization in the presence of FeCl3-RiH. 4 Conclusion In summary, we have developed an environmentally friendly, high yield and mild condition protocol for the preparation of acylals from various aldehydes using FeCl3-RiH as a new catalyst under solvent free conditions. This catalyst is also a suitable reagent for the regeneration of aldehydes from the related acylals in EtOH as a solvent. This method offers several advantages, compared to those reported in literature, i.e., (1) mild, highly efficient catalyst activity, (2) cost efficiency of the catalyst, (3) wide substrate scope (4) ease of product isolation/purification, (5) high yields of deprotected products, and (6) the reusability of the catalyst, making it a useful and attractive strategy for the synthesis of 1,1-diacetates and deprotection of the obtained 1,1-diacetates. coredata.dc:description: 1,1-Diacetates were produced from a variety of aromatic aldehydes using rice husk supported FeCl3 nanoparticles as a catalyst. The procedure generally resulted in good yields (98%) of aromatic aldehydes including those carrying electron donating- or withdrawing-substituents. Deprotection of the resulting 1,1-diacetates was also achieved using the same catalyst in ethanol. This new method consistently has the advantages of excellent yields and relatively short reaction times. Further, the catalyst can be reused and recovered for several times.
coredata.dc:title: Rice husk supported FeCl3 nanoparticles as an efficient and reusable catalyst for the chemoselective 1,1-diacetate protection and deprotection of aldehydes
